docs.lead_paragraph: Though poor children are known to be at higher risk for dental problems, few of their parents are taking advantage of a widely available anti-cavity procedure in which some teeth are coated with a plastic sealant, researchers say. The researchers, who studied the records of more than 15,000 North Carolina children over eight years, found that those who got sealants had about two-thirds as many fillings and extractions as children who were not treated.
docs.abstract: Study of North Carolina children finds that those whose teeth were coated with plastic sealant had about two-thirds as many fillings and extractions as children who were not treated, but that parents of only 23 percent of children took advantage of program, which is widely available and covered by Medicaid (S)
